item.title: Palliser's Smith On Activist Investing in Japan
item.description: Palliser Capital Founder & CIO James Smith discusses the prospects of activist investing in Japan. He speaks with Annabelle Droulers from the sidelines of 'Sohn Hong Kong Investment Leaders Conference'. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Jump India Said to Hire Akhtar From IMC in Top Technology Role
item.description: Jump India, the local arm of global market maker Jump Trading, has hired Javed Akhtar to lead its technology division, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Savio Shetty

media:content.media:description: Fiber optic cables, center, and copper Ethernet cables feed into switches inside a communications room at an office in London, U.K., on Monday, May 21, 2018. The Department of Culture, Media and Sport will work with the Home Office to publish a white paper later this year setting out legislation, according to a statement, which will also seek to force tech giants to reveal how they target abusive and illegal online material posted by users. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg

item.title: Chinese Shares Slide in Hong Kong on Renewed Trade Uncertainties
item.description: Chinese stocks fell in Hong Kong on Friday, after US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said trade talks between the world’s two largest economies are “a bit stalled.”
item.dc:creator: Sangmi Cha

item.title: Stocks, Futures Drop on Renewed Tariff Concerns: Markets Wrap
item.description: Asian shares and US stock futures fell on concern President Donald Trump’s tariffs are here to stay after his administration reiterated its resolve to keep the levies amid a legal tussle.
item.dc:creator: Anand Krishnamoorthy

item.title: China Hedge Fund Buying April Dip Extends Decade Gain to 1,485%
item.description: A Chinese hedge fund that bought the dip in April when the nation’s stocks plunged on fresh US tariffs has jumped 20% this year, extending its total return since inception a decade ago to 1,485%.
item.dc:creator: John Liu, Dingmin Zhang

media:content.media:description: A pedestrian along the Bund across from buildings in Pudong's Lujiazui Financial District during sunrise in Shanghai, China, on Thursday, Jan. 2, 2025. China’s gross domestic product is expected to expand around 5% for the full year of 2024, President Xi Jinping said, signaling the world’s second-largest economy is on track to meet its official target. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

item.title: Economists Warn ECB to Avoid Delaying Over Last Two Rate Cuts
item.description: The European Central Bank will lower interest rates twice more, according to a Bloomberg survey, but respondents warned it shouldn’t wait too long between those moves or investors will conclude that its easing campaign is already over.
item.dc:creator: Jana Randow, Harumi Ichikura

item.title: Ola Electric Plunges as Losses More Than Double Amid Sales Drop
item.description: Ola Electric Mobility Ltd. declined the most in more than a month, after reporting quarterly losses that more than doubled from a year ago as sales dropped.
item.dc:creator: Karthikeyan Sundaram

media:content.media:description: An advertisement hang at a newly-opened Ola Electric Mobility Ltd. store in New Delhi, India, on Wednesday, Dec. 25, 2024. Ola Electric announced opening of 3,200 new stores in a single day, as India’s biggest e-scooter maker seeks to expand its local footprint and address customer frustration related to shortcomings in service.

item.title: Congo’s Flooded Mine Is Latest Threat to World Copper Supply
item.description: The status of one of the world’s most important copper mines remains clouded in uncertainty, more than a week after seismic activity caused widespread flooding deep below ground.
item.dc:creator: William Clowes, Thomas Biesheuvel, Jack Farchy

media:content.media:description: The Kamoa Kakula mining site in Kamoa, Democratic Republic of Congo.

item.title: Convex Strategies CIO on Investment
item.description: Convex Strategies CIO David Dredge discusses his latest market outlook and investment strategies. He speaks with Annabelle Droulers from the sidelines of the “Sohn Hong Kong Investment Leaders Conference”. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Nickel Giant Tsingshan Cuts Indonesian Stainless Steel Output
item.description: The world’s biggest maker of stainless steel has suspended some production lines in Indonesia, in a bid to support prices as sluggish demand and trade uncertainty weigh on the market.
item.dc:creator: Annie Lee, Alfred Cang

item.title: NZ Defense Minister on Geopolitical Landscape
item.description: Judith Collins, New Zealand's Defense Minister, discusses the global geopolitcal landscape and growing New Zealand’s defense force. She speaks with Haslinda Amin from the sidelines of the "Shangri-La Dialogue" in Singapore. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Oasis Management's Fischer on Japan, Korea
item.description: Seth Fischer, Founder and CIO at Oasis Management, discusses the investment opportunities in Japan and Korea ahead of the "Sohn Hong Kong Investment Leaders Conference". He speaks with Annabelle Droulers and Haidi Stroud-Watts on "Bloomberg: The Asia Trade". (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Sharp Decline in Volatility Index Catches Seasoned Traders Off Guard
item.description: Before the trading day starts we bring you a digest of the key news and events that are likely to move markets. Today we look at:
item.dc:creator: Savio Shetty

item.title: Malaysian State to Start Using Durian Tracking System to Curb Fraud, Report Says
item.description: Malaysia’s state of Penang has urged its durian growers to register for a tracking system to curb the spread of counterfeit versions of the prickly, pungent fruit from June 1, according to Bernama.
item.dc:creator: Anisah Shukry

media:content.media:description: A trader sorts different quality and varieties of durian fruit into containers at a road side stall in Titi, Negeri Sembilan, Malaysia, on Monday, July 13, 2015. The Southeast Asian native fruit -- known for its sweet, custardy flesh and banned from Singapore's subways and hotels because of its pungent odor -- can retail for more than S$40 ($30) apiece in Singapore.

item.title: Nomura Sees Big Opportunities to Grow in US Despite Turmoil
item.description: Nomura Holdings Inc. is setting its sights on the US for growth despite the current turmoil surrounding the world’s biggest economy.
item.dc:creator: Takashi Nakamichi, Ryo Horiuchi

media:content.media:description: Signage for Nomura Holdings Inc. outside the company's Otemachi head office in Tokyo, Japan, on Wednesday, Oct. 30, 2024. Nomura is scheduled to announce it’s second-quarter earnings figures on Nov. 1. Photographer: Kiyoshi Ota/Bloomberg

item.title: UBS' MacLeod on Trade, Investor Sentiment
item.description: Niall MacLeod, Head of APAC Product Management at UBS, discusses the key highlights of the “UBS Asian Investment Conference”, and investor sentiment from clients. He speaks with David Ingles in Hong Kong. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: China Tech Alive And Well: JPMorgan
item.description: Chinese tech stocks are "alive and well" and remain attractive despite market turmoil, according to JPMorgan Asset Management APAC Equities Portfolio Manager Aisa Ogoshi. She speaks to Bloomberg TV's Paul Allen and Haidi Stroud-Watts on The Asia Trade. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Tariff Truce Keeps China-US Trade Flowing Across the Pacific
item.description: The ceasefire in the tariff fight between the world’s two largest economies is encouraging trade across the Pacific, holding up freight prices three weeks on, even as container bookings have begun to slow.
item.dc:creator: James Mayger, Katia Dmitrieva, Weilun Soon

item.title: Saudi Utility Eyes $10 Billion of Malaysia Renewable Projects
item.description: Saudi utility Acwa Power Co. signed non-binding agreements with Malaysian firms, including to explore development of about 13 gigawatts of power generation capacity, totaling $10 billion in investments by 2040.
item.dc:creator: Sing Yee Ong

media:content.media:description: A hydrogen bay at Petroleum Sarawak Bhd's multi-fuel station in Kuching, Sarawak, Malaysia, on Tuesday, Jan. 23, 2024. Sarawak in Malaysia has an abundance of rainfall and rivers, and powers its transport network with hydrogen. Photographer: Richard Humphries/Bloomberg

item.title: Japanese Life Insurers Cut Bullish Yen Hedges to 14-Year Low
item.description: Japanese life insurers cut protection for their foreign assets against a stronger yen to a fresh 14-year low, signaling subdued expectations of a sustained rally in the nation’s currency.
item.dc:creator: Masaki Kondo, Hidenori Yamanaka

item.title: Oil Poised for Second Weekly Loss Ahead of OPEC+ Supply Decision
item.description: Oil was on track for a second weekly decline ahead of an OPEC+ meeting on output policy that’s expected to lead to another supply hike.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Chen

media:content.media:description: Fuel and crude oil storage tanks at the Galp Energia SGPS SA Sines refinery plant in Sines, Portugal, on Tuesday, March 25, 2025. Galp expects its biofuels and green hydrogen projects located at the Sines refinery will be operating in mid-2026. Photographer: Goncalo Fonseca/Bloomberg

item.title: Li Auto Sales Outlook Misses Estimates Amid EV Price War
item.description: Li Auto Inc. forecast second-quarter revenue that missed estimates, as the Chinese electric vehicle maker struggles amid intensifying competition in the world’s biggest automobile market.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Yeo

media:content.media:description: Li Auto L6 at the Beijing Auto Show

item.title: Oil Tankers Going Dark Off Malaysia as Iran Trade Draws Scrutiny
item.description: Tankers involved in a vital hub of the Iran-to-China oil trade are disappearing from digital tracking systems, as the threat of US sanctions forces tactical changes to keep crude flowing.
item.dc:creator: Weilun Soon

item.title: Glencore Consolidates Global Coal Portfolio in Australian Entity
item.description: Mining and trading house Glencore Plc consolidated its global portfolio of coal and ferroalloy assets under one company registered in Australia, according to its annual report lodged with the country’s regulator.
item.dc:creator: Paul-Alain Hunt

media:content.media:description: A stacker-reclaimer at the Newcastle Coal Terminal in Newcastle, Australia, on Tuesday, April 22, 2025. The coal region of the Hunter is now grappling with the energy transition. Photographer: Brendon Thorne/Bloomberg

item.title: Why Trump’s ‘Golden Share’ in US Steel May Lack Some Luster
item.description: The US government could receive a so-called golden share — or powers akin to it — in United States Steel Corp. as a condition for approving a $14 billion takeover by Japan’s Nippon Steel Corp.
item.dc:creator: Yiqin Shen

media:content.media:description: A water tower at the US Steel Corp. Edgar Thomson Works steel mill in Braddock, Pennsylvania.

item.title: Gold Holds Gain as Fresh Trade Uncertainty Stokes Haven Demand
item.description: Gold recovered some heavy losses sustained earlier this week, as markets were once again rattled by uncertainties around US President Donald Trump’s global tariffs agenda and the strength of the US economy.
item.dc:creator: Sybilla Gross

media:content.media:description: Gold bullions at the YLG Bullion International Co. headquarters in Bangkok, Thailand, on Friday, Dec. 22, 2023. Gold headed for a weekly gain after US price data came in cooler than forecast, reinforcing expectations for multiple interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve next year. Photographer: Chalinee Thirasupa/Bloomberg

item.title: High-Yielding Bonds in EM May Beat Peers as Treasuries Decline
item.description: Riskier emerging-market bonds may continue to beat their lower-yielding peers as the dollar’s slide softens a rise in Treasury yields, protecting investor returns, according to analysis by Bloomberg.
item.dc:creator: Marcus Wong

item.title: NetEase Shares Near Record High as China’s Gen Z Embraces Games
item.description: NetEase Inc. shares are closing in on their first new all-time high in over four years, as a wave of youthful consumerism adds to a host of positives for China’s game stocks.
item.dc:creator: Henry Ren, Sangmi Cha

item.title: Tariff Turmoil Leads Global Funds to Pile Back Into Japan Stocks
item.description: Tariff turmoil is drawing global investors back to Japan’s stock market, as prospects of better shareholder returns entice funds fleeing economic uncertainty in the US.
item.dc:creator: Alice French

item.title: Chinese Banks Face Liquidity Test on Deposit Exodus, Maturities
item.description: Chinese banks are set for a liquidity test in June as they face record debt maturities and a potential exodus from deposits.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Zhu, Wenjin Lv, Jing Zhao
